canonical_explanation.text: Plants are unique living organisms that can make their own food through a process called photosynthesis. During photosynthesis, plants use sunlight, water (from soil through roots), and carbon dioxide (from air through stomata in leaves) to make glucose (food) and release oxygen. Chlorophyll, the green pigment in leaves, captures sunlight energy. Plants also respire, taking in oxygen and releasing carbon dioxide, just like animals. Respiration occurs all day and night, while photosynthesis only happens during the day. Plants reproduce through seeds (sexual reproduction) and through vegetative parts like stems, roots, and leaves (vegetative reproduction). Seed germination requires water, air (oxygen), and warmth. Seeds are dispersed by wind, water, animals, and by bursting.
rules: Photosynthesis: plants make food using sunlight, water, and carbon dioxide
Chlorophyll in leaves captures sunlight energy
Products of photosynthesis: glucose (food) and oxygen
Stomata are tiny pores on leaves for gas exchange
Plants respire: take in oxygen, release carbon dioxide
Respiration happens day and night; photosynthesis only during daytime
Seed parts: seed coat, cotyledon (food store), embryo (baby plant)
Seed dispersal: by wind, water, animals, and bursting
Vegetative reproduction: new plant from stem cutting, root, or leaf

questions.question_text: The process by which plants make their own food is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Photosynthesis is the process by which plants make their own food. 'Photo' means light and 'synthesis' means to make. Plants use sunlight, water, and carbon dioxide to make glucose and oxygen.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Respiration is the process of breaking down food for energy, digestion happens in animals, and germination is when a seed starts to grow. Photosynthesis is the specific process where plants make food using sunlight.

questions.question_text: Which part of the plant is mainly responsible for photosynthesis?
questions.explanation_correct: Leaves are mainly responsible for photosynthesis because they contain chlorophyll, the green pigment that captures sunlight energy. Leaves are broad and flat to absorb maximum sunlight.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Roots absorb water from the soil, the stem transports water and food, and flowers are for reproduction. Leaves are the main site of photosynthesis because they contain chlorophyll.

questions.question_text: The green colour of leaves is due to a pigment called:
questions.explanation_correct: Chlorophyll is the green pigment found in the leaves of plants. It captures sunlight energy which is used in the process of photosynthesis to make food.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Haemoglobin makes blood red, melanin gives colour to skin and hair, and carotene is an orange pigment. Chlorophyll is the green pigment in leaves that is essential for photosynthesis.

questions.question_text: Plants are called producers because they make their own food.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Plants are called producers because they produce (make) their own food through photosynthesis. They do not depend on other organisms for food, unlike animals which are called consumers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is true. Plants make their own food using sunlight, water, and carbon dioxide through photosynthesis, which is why they are called producers.

questions.question_text: Radha noticed that the leaves of a plant kept in a dark room turned yellow after a few days. Why did this happen?

options.text: The plant got too much water
Without sunlight, chlorophyll breaks down and the plant cannot make food

questions.explanation_correct: Without sunlight, the chlorophyll in the leaves breaks down and is not replaced. Chlorophyll gives leaves their green colour, so when it breaks down, the leaves turn yellow. Also, without sunlight, the plant cannot make food through photosynthesis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The yellowing is not due to too much water, cold temperature, or painting. It happens because sunlight is essential for maintaining chlorophyll. Without light, chlorophyll degrades, the leaves lose their green colour, and the plant cannot photosynthesise.

questions.question_text: Why do most plants have broad, flat leaves?

options.text: To absorb maximum sunlight for photosynthesis
To protect the plant from rain

questions.explanation_correct: Most plants have broad, flat leaves to absorb maximum sunlight. The larger the surface area exposed to sunlight, the more light energy the chlorophyll can capture for photosynthesis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While leaves may look beautiful, their broad, flat shape has a scientific purpose. It allows them to capture as much sunlight as possible, which is needed for photosynthesis. This is an adaptation to maximise food production.

questions.question_text: Without photosynthesis, life on Earth would be impossible. The main reason is:

options.text: There would be no food or oxygen for other living things

questions.explanation_correct: Photosynthesis produces food (glucose) and oxygen. Without it, plants could not make food for themselves or for the animals that eat them. Also, the oxygen we breathe comes mainly from photosynthesis. So without photosynthesis, there would be no food chain and no oxygen for breathing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The sun would still shine and water would not disappear without photosynthesis. The critical issue is that photosynthesis provides the food and oxygen that almost all living things on Earth depend on.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is needed by plants for photosynthesis?
questions.explanation_correct: Plants need sunlight, water, and carbon dioxide for photosynthesis. Sunlight provides energy, water comes from the soil through roots, and carbon dioxide enters through tiny pores called stomata on leaves.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Photosynthesis needs sunlight (not moonlight or darkness), water (from soil), and carbon dioxide (from air). Oxygen is produced, not used, in photosynthesis. Nitrogen and soil are not direct requirements.

questions.question_text: Where do plants get water for photosynthesis?
questions.explanation_correct: Plants absorb water from the soil through their roots. The water then travels up through the stem to the leaves where it is used in photosynthesis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plants get water from the soil, not from air, sun, or other plants. The roots absorb water from the soil, and it travels through the stem to reach the leaves for photosynthesis.

questions.question_text: Tiny pores on the surface of leaves through which gases enter and exit are called:
questions.explanation_correct: Stomata (singular: stoma) are tiny pores found mainly on the underside of leaves. Carbon dioxide enters the leaf through stomata for photosynthesis, and oxygen and water vapour exit through them.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Roots absorb water from soil, veins carry water in the leaf, and petals are parts of flowers. Stomata are the tiny openings on leaves that allow gases to move in and out.

questions.question_text: What are the products of photosynthesis?
questions.explanation_correct: The products of photosynthesis are glucose (food) and oxygen. Glucose is used by the plant for energy and growth, and oxygen is released into the air, which is essential for animals and humans to breathe.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Water and carbon dioxide are the raw materials (inputs) for photosynthesis, not the products. Sunlight is the energy source. The products that are made during photosynthesis are glucose (sugar/food) and oxygen.

questions.question_text: Arun covers a leaf with black paper for three days, then tests it for starch. He finds no starch in the covered part. What does this prove?

options.text: The leaf does not need water
The leaf does not need carbon dioxide

questions.explanation_correct: This experiment proves that sunlight is necessary for photosynthesis. The covered part did not receive sunlight, so photosynthesis could not occur and no starch (food) was produced. The uncovered part would have starch because it received sunlight.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The leaf is not dead; only the part covered with black paper could not photosynthesise. By blocking sunlight from reaching that part of the leaf, the experiment shows that without sunlight, plants cannot make food (starch).

questions.question_text: The simple word equation for photosynthesis is:

options.text: Glucose + Oxygen → Carbon dioxide + Water + Energy
Carbon dioxide + Water → Glucose + Oxygen (in the presence of sunlight and chlorophyll)

questions.explanation_correct: The word equation for photosynthesis is: Carbon dioxide + Water → Glucose + Oxygen (in the presence of sunlight and chlorophyll). This shows that plants use carbon dioxide and water as raw materials and produce glucose and oxygen.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A describes respiration, not photosynthesis. Options C and D have incorrect combinations. The correct equation shows carbon dioxide and water as inputs, with glucose and oxygen as outputs, requiring sunlight and chlorophyll.

questions.question_text: Do plants respire (breathe)?

options.text: Plants respire only during the day

questions.explanation_correct: Yes, plants also respire. Like animals, plants take in oxygen and release carbon dioxide during respiration. This process happens all the time, both day and night, to release energy from food.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plants do respire, not just animals. And they respire all the time - both day and night, not just at one time. During respiration, plants take in oxygen and release carbon dioxide to get energy from the food they make.

questions.question_text: During respiration, plants take in _____ and release _____.
questions.explanation_correct: During respiration, plants take in oxygen and release carbon dioxide. This is the same as what animals do during breathing. Respiration breaks down glucose using oxygen to release energy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: During respiration (not photosynthesis), plants take in oxygen and release carbon dioxide. This is the opposite of photosynthesis. Do not confuse the two processes.

questions.question_text: Photosynthesis happens all day and night, just like respiration.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. Photosynthesis happens only during the day when sunlight is available. Respiration happens all the time, both day and night. Plants need sunlight for photosynthesis, so it cannot occur in the dark.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is false. While respiration does occur day and night, photosynthesis only happens during the day because it requires sunlight. At night, only respiration takes place in plants.

questions.question_text: Why is it not advisable to sleep under trees at night?

options.text: Trees release poisonous gases at night
At night, trees only respire, releasing carbon dioxide and using up oxygen
Trees attract dangerous animals at night

questions.explanation_correct: At night, trees only respire (no photosynthesis without sunlight). During respiration, they take in oxygen and release carbon dioxide. This can reduce oxygen levels near the tree, making it less healthy to sleep there. During the day, photosynthesis produces more oxygen than respiration uses.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Trees do not release poisonous gases, and they do not stop breathing at night. The correct reason is that at night, trees only respire (releasing carbon dioxide) because photosynthesis requires sunlight and cannot occur in darkness.

questions.question_text: How is photosynthesis different from respiration in plants?

options.text: Photosynthesis uses oxygen; respiration uses carbon dioxide
Photosynthesis makes food and releases oxygen; respiration breaks down food and releases carbon dioxide
Photosynthesis happens at night; respiration happens during the day

questions.explanation_correct: In photosynthesis, plants make food (glucose) using carbon dioxide and water, and release oxygen. In respiration, plants break down food using oxygen and release carbon dioxide and energy. They are opposite processes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A has the gases reversed. Option C has the timing wrong (photosynthesis is during the day, respiration is all the time). There is definitely a difference between the two processes. Photosynthesis makes food; respiration breaks it down for energy.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a method of seed dispersal?
questions.explanation_correct: Wind is one of the common methods of seed dispersal. Seeds of plants like dandelion and maple have lightweight structures or wings that help them float in the wind and travel to new places.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Electricity, sound, and magnetism do not disperse seeds. Seeds are dispersed by wind, water, animals, and by bursting (explosion). These natural methods help seeds travel to new locations where they can grow.

questions.question_text: Coconut seeds are dispersed mainly by:
questions.explanation_correct: Coconut seeds are dispersed mainly by water. Coconuts can float on water because they have a fibrous outer covering. They travel across rivers and seas to reach new shores where they can grow into new coconut trees.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Coconuts are too heavy to be dispersed by wind and too large for animal dispersal. They do not burst. Coconuts float on water and are carried by ocean currents and rivers to new locations.

questions.question_text: Some fruits have hooks or spines that stick to animal fur. This helps in seed dispersal by:
questions.explanation_correct: Fruits with hooks or spines stick to the fur of animals or clothes of people. As the animals move from one place to another, the seeds are carried along and eventually fall off in new locations. This is dispersal by animals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hooks and spines on fruits are specifically an adaptation for dispersal by animals. They cling to animal fur and are transported to new places. Xanthium (gokhru) is a common Indian example of a plant with hooked fruits.

questions.question_text: Balsam pods burst open suddenly when ripe, scattering seeds in all directions. This is an example of seed dispersal by:
questions.explanation_correct: Balsam is an example of seed dispersal by bursting (explosion). When the pods are ripe and dry, they burst open suddenly, flinging the seeds away from the parent plant. Pea pods also scatter seeds this way.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The seeds are not carried by wind, water, or animals in this case. The pods themselves burst open with force, scattering the seeds. This is called dispersal by explosion or bursting.

questions.question_text: Why is seed dispersal important for plants?

options.text: It prevents overcrowding and helps plants grow in new places
It gives food to animals only

questions.explanation_correct: Seed dispersal is important because it prevents overcrowding. If all seeds fell near the parent plant, they would compete for sunlight, water, and space. Dispersal helps seeds reach new places where they have a better chance of growing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Seed dispersal does not make seeds taste better or bigger. While it may help feed animals, the main purpose is to spread seeds to new locations to avoid competition and help the plant species survive in different areas.

questions.question_text:
Match the plant with its method of seed dispersal:
(i) Dandelion - (a) Water
(ii) Coconut - (b) Bursting
(iii) Balsam - (c) Wind
Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct match is: Dandelion - Wind (c) because its seeds have fluffy parachute-like structures, Coconut - Water (a) because it floats and travels by sea, Balsam - Bursting (b) because its pods burst open when ripe.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Remember: Dandelion seeds float in the wind (like tiny parachutes). Coconuts float on water. Balsam pods burst open. The correct matching is (i)-c, (ii)-a, (iii)-b.

questions.question_text: A rose plant can grow a new plant from a stem cutting placed in moist soil. This type of reproduction is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Growing a new plant from a stem cutting is called vegetative reproduction. It does not involve seeds. The new plant grows from a vegetative part (stem, root, or leaf) of the parent plant. Rose, money plant, and sugarcane are commonly grown this way.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Seed germination involves seeds. Photosynthesis is food-making. Pollination is transfer of pollen. Vegetative reproduction is the correct term for growing new plants from parts like stems, roots, or leaves.

questions.question_text: What are the three conditions needed for a seed to germinate?
questions.explanation_correct: The three conditions needed for seed germination are water, air (oxygen), and warmth (suitable temperature). Water softens the seed coat, oxygen helps in respiration, and warmth provides the right temperature for growth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sunlight is not immediately needed for germination (seeds can germinate in the dark). Soil provides support but seeds can germinate on wet cotton too. The essential conditions are water, air, and warmth.

questions.question_text: The part of the seed that contains the baby plant is called the:
questions.explanation_correct: The embryo is the baby plant inside the seed. When the seed germinates, the embryo grows into a new plant. It contains the tiny root, stem, and leaves of the future plant.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The seed coat is the protective outer covering, and the cotyledon stores food for the baby plant. The embryo is the part that contains the baby plant and develops into a new plant during germination.

questions.question_text: The thick, fleshy part of a bean seed that stores food for the baby plant is called the:
questions.explanation_correct: The cotyledon is the thick, fleshy part of the seed that stores food for the baby plant (embryo). In a bean or rajma seed, the two large halves you see when you split it open are the cotyledons.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The embryo is the baby plant, and the seed coat is the outer covering. The cotyledon is the food storage part. When a seed germinates, the cotyledon provides nutrition until the young plant can make its own food.

questions.question_text: Nisha soaked rajma seeds in water overnight. She noticed they became swollen. Why did this happen?

options.text: The seeds absorbed water through the seed coat

questions.explanation_correct: The rajma seeds absorbed water through the seed coat, causing them to swell. This is the first step in germination. Water softens the seed coat and activates the embryo inside the seed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Seeds absorb water (not air) through their seed coat. They do not grow flowers immediately or turn water into seeds. The absorption of water causes the seed to swell, which is the beginning of the germination process.

questions.question_text: Anil placed some moong seeds on wet cotton in a dish. Another set of seeds he placed on dry cotton. After 3 days, only the seeds on wet cotton sprouted. What does this show?

options.text: Water is necessary for seed germination

questions.explanation_correct: This experiment shows that water is necessary for seed germination. The seeds on wet cotton had water available and germinated, while the seeds on dry cotton did not germinate because they lacked water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cotton and dish are not what make the seeds grow. The key difference was the presence or absence of water. Seeds on wet cotton sprouted because they had water, proving that water is essential for germination.

questions.question_text: During germination, which part of the seed emerges first?
questions.explanation_correct: During germination, the root (radicle) emerges first. It grows downward into the soil to anchor the plant and absorb water and minerals. After the root, the shoot grows upward.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Flowers and fruits come much later in the plant's life. The leaf appears after the shoot grows. The first part to emerge during germination is the radicle (root), which grows downward to anchor the seedling and absorb water.

questions.question_text: The green pigment in leaves that helps capture sunlight is called _____.
questions.explanation_correct: Chlorophyll is the green pigment in leaves that captures sunlight energy for photosynthesis. It is found inside chloroplasts in the leaf cells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Haemoglobin is a pigment in blood. Cytoplasm and nucleus are cell parts. Chlorophyll is the specific green pigment found in leaves that captures sunlight for making food.

questions.question_text: During photosynthesis, plants take in carbon dioxide and release _____.
questions.explanation_correct: During photosynthesis, plants take in carbon dioxide and release oxygen. This oxygen is essential for all animals and humans to breathe. Trees and plants are therefore very important for maintaining oxygen in the atmosphere.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plants release oxygen (not nitrogen, more carbon dioxide, or hydrogen) during photosynthesis. This is one of the most important contributions of plants to the environment.

questions.question_text: Which of the following plants can grow from a stem cutting?
questions.explanation_correct: Rose plants can be grown from stem cuttings. A healthy stem piece is cut and planted in moist soil, and it develops roots and grows into a new plant. This is called vegetative reproduction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Wheat and rice are grown from seeds. Mango trees are usually grown from seeds or grafting. Rose is a common example of a plant that is easily propagated through stem cuttings.

questions.question_text: During the day, do plants take in carbon dioxide or oxygen or both?

options.text: Both carbon dioxide (for photosynthesis) and oxygen (for respiration)

questions.explanation_correct: During the day, plants take in both gases. They take in carbon dioxide for photosynthesis and oxygen for respiration. Both processes happen simultaneously during the day. However, photosynthesis produces much more oxygen than respiration uses.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plants carry out both photosynthesis and respiration during the day. Photosynthesis uses carbon dioxide, and respiration uses oxygen. Both processes happen at the same time when sunlight is available.

questions.question_text: The protective outer covering of a seed is called the:
questions.explanation_correct: The seed coat is the protective outer covering of a seed. It protects the embryo and cotyledon inside from damage, insects, and unfavourable conditions until the seed is ready to germinate.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cotyledon stores food, the embryo is the baby plant, and petals are parts of flowers. The seed coat is the tough outer layer that protects the seed.

questions.question_text: Potato plants can grow from the eyes (buds) of a potato tuber. This is vegetative reproduction.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Potato plants grow from the buds (called eyes) on potato tubers. This is a type of vegetative reproduction because a new plant grows from a part of the parent plant, not from a seed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is true. The eyes on a potato tuber are buds that can sprout and grow into new potato plants. Since no seeds are involved, this is vegetative reproduction.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a raw material for photosynthesis?
questions.explanation_correct: Oxygen is NOT a raw material for photosynthesis; it is a product. The raw materials are water and carbon dioxide, and sunlight provides the energy. Oxygen is released as a by-product of photosynthesis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Water and carbon dioxide are raw materials used in photosynthesis, and sunlight provides energy. Oxygen is produced during photosynthesis, not used as a raw material.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: Green plants are called autotrophs.
Reason: They can make their own food through photosynthesis.
Choose the correct option.

options.text: Both assertion and reason are true, and the reason explains the assertion
Both assertion and reason are true, but the reason does not explain the assertion
The assertion is true but the reason is false

questions.explanation_correct: Both statements are true. Green plants are called autotrophs (auto = self, troph = food) because they make their own food through photosynthesis. The reason directly explains why they are called autotrophs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The assertion is true (plants are autotrophs) and the reason is also true (they make food through photosynthesis). The reason correctly explains the assertion because 'autotroph' literally means 'self-feeding.'

questions.question_text: Seema stores seeds in a cool, dry place in an airtight container. Why is this a good method?

options.text: It helps the seeds germinate faster
It prevents germination by keeping seeds away from moisture, warmth, and air
It adds nutrients to the seeds

questions.explanation_correct: Storing seeds in a cool, dry, airtight container prevents germination because the seeds are kept away from the three conditions needed for germination: water (moisture), warmth, and air (oxygen). This keeps the seeds safe for a long time.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The purpose of storing seeds this way is to prevent them from germinating too early, not to help them germinate. By removing moisture, warmth, and air, the seeds remain dormant and can be stored for a long time.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly compares photosynthesis and respiration in plants?

options.text: Both occur only during the day
Photosynthesis stores energy; respiration releases energy

questions.explanation_correct: Photosynthesis stores energy in the form of food (glucose), while respiration releases that stored energy for the plant to use. This is a key difference between the two processes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Only photosynthesis produces oxygen; respiration uses it. Respiration occurs day and night, not only during the day. Only photosynthesis requires sunlight. The correct comparison is that photosynthesis stores energy and respiration releases it.

questions.question_text:
Money plant, sugarcane, and bryophyllum can all reproduce vegetatively. Which part is used for each?
(i) Money plant - stem cutting
(ii) Sugarcane - stem cutting
(iii) Bryophyllum - leaf
Are these correct?
questions.explanation_correct: All three are correct. Money plant grows from stem cuttings placed in water or soil. Sugarcane is grown by planting stem pieces with nodes. Bryophyllum (patharchatta) grows new plantlets from the edges of its leaves.
questions.explanation_incorrect: All three statements are correct. Money plant and sugarcane reproduce through stem cuttings, and bryophyllum reproduces through its leaves. These are all examples of vegetative reproduction.

questions.question_text: The three main parts of a seed are the seed coat, _____, and embryo.
questions.explanation_correct: The three main parts of a seed are the seed coat (protective covering), cotyledon (food storage), and embryo (baby plant). The cotyledon provides food to the embryo during germination.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Roots, leaves, and flowers develop after the seed germinates. Inside the seed, the three parts are the seed coat, cotyledon, and embryo.

questions.question_text: Farmers in India grow more trees to help the environment. Which gas do trees release during photosynthesis that helps us breathe?
questions.explanation_correct: Trees release oxygen during photosynthesis. Oxygen is the gas that all animals and humans need to breathe. This is why planting more trees is good for the environment - they clean the air and provide oxygen.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Trees release oxygen (not carbon dioxide, nitrogen, or hydrogen) during photosynthesis. This oxygen is essential for the survival of humans and animals. More trees mean more oxygen and cleaner air.

questions.question_text: Photosynthesis can occur even without chlorophyll.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. Chlorophyll is essential for photosynthesis. It is the green pigment that captures sunlight energy needed to convert carbon dioxide and water into food. Without chlorophyll, photosynthesis cannot take place.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is false. Chlorophyll is absolutely necessary for photosynthesis. It captures the sunlight energy that drives the entire process. Without it, plants cannot make food.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of vegetative reproduction?

options.text: A mango growing from a seed
A new potato plant growing from a potato eye (bud)

questions.explanation_correct: A new potato plant growing from a potato eye (bud) is vegetative reproduction. The new plant grows from a part of the parent plant (the tuber) without involving seeds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Growing from a seed (mango) and producing seeds (sunflower) are not vegetative reproduction. A bird eating fruit is seed dispersal by animals. Vegetative reproduction is when a new plant grows from a part of the parent plant without seeds.

questions.question_text: Which of the following seeds is most likely dispersed by wind?
questions.explanation_correct: Dandelion seeds are dispersed by wind. They are very light and have fluffy, parachute-like structures that allow them to float in the air and travel long distances with the wind.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mango seeds are too heavy for wind. Coconuts are dispersed by water. Balsam seeds are dispersed by bursting. Dandelion seeds are light with fluffy structures specifically adapted for wind dispersal.

questions.question_text: Kiran's mother places a money plant stem in a glass of water near a window. After a week, she notices roots growing from the stem. What helped the plant grow roots?

options.text: The plant absorbed water and used sunlight for energy to grow roots

questions.explanation_correct: The money plant stem absorbed water and used the sunlight coming through the window for energy (photosynthesis) to grow new roots. Water and light together helped the plant grow and establish itself.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The glass and window are not what caused root growth. The plant used water (absorbed through the stem) and sunlight (through the window) for energy to grow new roots. This is an example of vegetative reproduction.

questions.question_text: At night, plants:

options.text: Carry out both photosynthesis and respiration
Do not carry out any life process

questions.explanation_correct: At night, plants only carry out respiration because there is no sunlight for photosynthesis. During respiration, they take in oxygen and release carbon dioxide, just like animals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Photosynthesis requires sunlight and cannot happen at night. Plants do not stop all life processes at night. At night, only respiration continues, where plants use oxygen and release carbon dioxide.

questions.question_text:
Ravi placed seeds in three conditions:
Set A: Wet cotton, in a warm room
Set B: Dry cotton, in a warm room
Set C: Wet cotton, inside a freezer
Which set would germinate?
questions.explanation_correct: Only Set A would germinate because it has all three conditions needed: water (wet cotton), air (not sealed), and warmth (warm room). Set B lacks water (dry cotton), and Set C lacks warmth (freezer is too cold).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Set B would not germinate because the cotton is dry (no water). Set C would not germinate because the freezer is too cold (no warmth). Only Set A has all three essential conditions: water, air, and suitable temperature.
